text:
The great irony of this entire thing is that
I couldn’t fall asleep last night because

I knew the text line was going to break overnight
while I was asleep and there was nothing I
could do about it.

Okay, you’re probably wondering what on
earth I’m talking about.
Let me explain…

​​I don’t know about you but I get so
many spam text messages and phone calls, and
they’re so annoying.
And one day when I was reading “Hello!
You earned 2 points buying bread!”

I thought, is there a way these can be used
for good?

So, I spent the last three months, a lot of
time, and a fair bit of money creating a text
message bot.

But instead of annoying you it’s actually
designed to help improve your sleep.

And I’m about to find out if it actually
worked.

This all started about a year ago, when I
set up a Google Alert for Bedtime Procrastination

– a phenomenon where you put off going to
bed, in favour of the short-term benefits

from late night activities, like gaming, watching
TV or scrolling through your phone.

You might justify it to yourself at the time,
so you can have more time to yourself, some
“me” time.
You deserve it!

Or you might just be on autopilot and not
even realise you’re doing it.

Basically I wanted to make a video about this,
so this Alert emailed me when new research
or articles came out.
And then… things exploded.

Bedtime Procrastination became such a hot
topic that every media outlet wrote about
it.

Now these articles focused on what we know
about Bedtime Procrastination –

It's linked to shorter sleep, poor sleep quality
and being fatigued the next day – which
is bad for your mental and physical health.

So it became the missing link in our collective
languishing, the new thing we could identify

as bad and, potentially, feel guilty about
doing.
But like everything, it’s nuanced.

Sometimes bedtime procrastination isn’t
that bad for you, because you might be able

to push back what time you start school or
work the next day, so you get the same amount
of sleep.

For some people, you really need that “me
time” because it’s the only time you get

to yourself all day – you can do whatever
you want and you’re kinda taking revenge

on your busy schedule that you don’t get
control of.

But for others, bedtime procrastination is
a real problem and it leads them to be chronically
sleep deprived.

And the one thing that bothered me was that,
for those people who do want to change, there

wasn’t a lot of info out there on how you
can do that.

Many of these articles just gave a laundry
list of sleep hygiene, like “put away your
phone” or “stick to a routine.”

It may seem counterintuitive, but a list of
tips is one of the worst ways to get people
to change their behaviour.

In research, providing information about your
health doesn't lead to change.

It also presumes that all of your behaviour
is coming from a place of self-control, like,

you just need more of that self-control to
go to bed on time.

And a big list of things you’re not doing
is kind of overwhelming!

So for those who want to change, it’s important
to note that it isn’t a problem of willpower
or self-control, but a problem of strategy.

And luckily, there are plans and strategies
that we can implement to tweak our behaviour.
And this is where the hotline comes in.

I wanted to try to help you create a strategy
specific to your goals and life, but in a

way where I could communicate with you more
generically (through the text line) and then

you could take away something more personal
and meaningful.

One way this has been done successfully in
research is when people create an Implementation
Intention.

This is basically an If/Then plan that you
create to have a cue to tweak your behaviour
and even form new habits.

For example, say you want to write a short
story.

You might create a plan like, “If I’m
drinking coffee, then I will write 300 words.”

Or you want to get fit, so you say “If I
open up the reddit app, then I will pause
to do two sets of lunges.”

The possibilities are endless, but the point
is that you’re more likely to act on your
intentions with a specific plan in place.

In the context of sleep, you might create
a scenario that says, “If the clock strikes

11pm, then I will stop watching YouTube and
start brushing my teeth.

So I’m trying to figure out how to get you
to devise an implementation intention through
text messages and there’s a couple of challenges:

The messages I send can only be 160 characters
Emojis take up 2 characters so I had to scrap

all emojis, which is sad, because normally
I text like a 70 year-old-woman so it’s

about 50% emojis
I have to pay per text message that I send,
about (cost) so I’m trying to not go broke.

I want to try to do this well but in as few
messages as possible

I don’t want to collect all of your personal
information, and it’s actually hard to use

a mass text messaging service in a way that
keeps your information anonymous

I need to use the right language and cue your
thinking in a particular sequence so this

can actually work
I’ve currently been doing this for 2 months,

and because I’m travelling you’re going
to see me in maybe 5 different locations trying
to make this work

Which segues us to our next location, and
a very important side note.

So, text message marketing services are designed
to capture as much of your information as
they possibly can.

But it’s important to note, and I really
want you all to know, that I designed an anonymous

survey so I didn’t actually collect anyone’s
data, or information, or phone number.

All I could see was the locations that they
were coming from, so the area code basically.

This whole process was opt-in, so it was not
my intention to spam people.
Just wanted you all to know that.

And after a few more weeks of testing, refining
the language and convincing all of my family

and friends that they should text “SLEEP”
to a random number to see what happened, the
text line was up and running.

I told you all about it through one of these
#shorts and we were up and, well, you broke
it.
Kinda.
In a good way.
Hi!

I'm a current customer and I'm interested
in upgrading my plan.

So when I set up the hotline I thought it
was a cool thing to do, but I didn't think
it was going to be that popular.

So I bought 500 text messages, and they ran
out in 2 hours.

I underestimated all of you and for that,
I'm sorry.

I wanted to upgrade to the one that's 2000
messages a month.

I've tried to do it a few times yesterday
and today, but I keep getting an error message.

Okay. great thanks so much, so you're going
to call me in a moment?
Cool, thank you.
Maybe it's going to be fixed?
We don't know yet.

This is a good time to thank my Patrons, for
supporting not only my channel, but these
weird experiments that I get to do.
There are two things that we discovered today.

One is that people are far more interested
in bedtime procrastination and participating

in my weird experiments than I would have
expected.

And the second is that bedtime procrastination
is a byproduct of capitalism.
The plan has upgraded.
Okay, time for the results…

So, overall, everybody thought about their
evening routine more frequently, which is
pretty expected.

If you fill in a survey or receive text messages
talking about your evening routine you’re

probably going to think about it more straight
after.

About half of the people who participated
reported making a change to their evening
routine, which is kind of incredible…

Now, this had a stronger effect closer to
when people took the survey, and what I mean

by that is people who took the survey less
than a week ago or a week ago, the majority

of them reported making a change to their
evening routine.

But those who took the survey two weeks ago,
or more than two weeks ago, reported not really
making a change.

So, there was kind of a fading of the effect
of doing
the survey.

And this is why a laundry list of solutions
is not effective for real behaviour change,

and often just results in us feeling bad about
not reaching a goal.

And, now, thanks to the message bot and your
responses, I know exactly what late night

activities are keeping you all from going
to bed.

Youtube, Instagram, Watching Youtube videos
on end, Tinder, watching your videos, playing

video games, reddit, discord, watching BrainCraft,
books, porn, vacuuming.
Who wants to vacuum?
Ever?

Needless to say, you all are procrastinating
sleep but keeping the algorithms very alive.

Now the one thing that we can’t tell is
if people got more sleep.

I didn’t measure sleep, maybe we’ll do
that next time.

I think it is just incredible that people
are thinking about their evening routine,

that they’re trying to have healthier behaviours,
and I’m going to take that.
I’m happy with that.

Okay so for the rest of you guys who want
to stop procrastinating so much in the evening,

if that is a goal that you have, think about
tweaking your environment in a way that's
conducive to you achieving that goal.

You can start by thinking through your evening
routine and try to identify those activities
you're using to procrastinate.
I think it's YouTube... for a lot of you.
I just have that feeling.

I'm not saying stop watching YouTube, obviously,
but you might just set some reasonable parameters

around that of how much time you want to spend
doing that every evening.

And if you do want to stop procrastinating
before you go to bed, you can set your own
if/then plan for that.
Remember to be really specific.

So you might say, "when my bedtime alarm goes
off at 11 o'clock I'm going to put my phone

in the kitchen, turn it on do-not-disturb,
and start my nighttime routine."

Which is what I try to do, and I do it like
three nights a week, so it's moderately successful.
This is really hard, okay?

The worst thing you can do is to feel bad
about not doing the right thing, because at

the end of the day there is no correct way
to have an evening routine or to get the best
sleep really.
You just have to do what works for you.
And that’s okay.

As Matt Haig has said, find a routine that
is baggy enough to live in.

Thank you so much to all of my patrons (What
absolute legends!) that support BrainCraft,

and also these weird experiments that we can
do.

I have actually set up a BrainCraft Discord
server, so if you join at the $2 tier, you’ll

be able to participate in planning, and designing,
and even executing the next experiment that
we’re doing.

It’s my goal just to do these weird experiments
on the internet because I love them.

They’re so fun, and we find out such cool
things about human behaviour.
